response.answer_text: Ashwasena (अश्‍वसेन) was son of Naga Takshaka, whose mother Arjuna had slain. He was saved by Indra, while Khandavavana was put into flame by Pandavas. Once, when Krishna and Arjuna were staying on the banks of the Yamuna in summer, Agni requested them to help him consume the Khandava forest. Arjuna agreed to help him, and Agni gave him the Gandiva, a white horse and several divine weapons. When Agni started consuming the forest, it began raining, at Indra’s command. Arjuna made a layer of arrows to block the rain. Ashwasena tried to escape but was blocked by Arjuna’s arrow. Ashwasena’s mother swallowed him and helped him escape the fire, but Arjuna’s arrrow beheaded her. Indra then tried to save Ashwasena by sending a fresh burst of wind and rains. Arjuna fell unconscious in that onslaught and Ashwasena managed to escape. During the Mahabharata war, when Arjuna fought Karna, the Naga King Ashwasena desirous of avenging the death of his mother from Arjuna, in that battle quietly slips into the quiver of Karna in the guise of an Arrow. It is this Arrow that had almost killed Arjuna had it not been for Krishna who by pressing his feet on the chariot sank it one cubit deep into the earth hence the arrow missing its aim. Whether Ashwasena was on the tip or not, the celestial weapon would have destroyed Arjuna. This was why Krishna deliberately sunk the chariot into the ground - to save Arjuna from The Nagastra and not from Ashwasena.

A little known story is that at the time of the great war when Arjuna and Karna come face to face with each other, the Naga King Ashwasena desirous of avenging the death of his mother from Arjuna, in that battle quietly slips into the quiver of Karna in the guise of an Arrow. It is this Arrow that had almost killed Arjuna had it not been for Krishna who by pressing his feet on the chariot sank it one cubit deep into the earth hence the arrow missing its aim.
